Define what qualifies as a diagonal in the context of a convex polygon.
Calculate the total number of diagonals that can be drawn from the n vertices of the polygon.
Identify the condition for two diagonals to intersect within the interior of the polygon.
Determine the criterion for choosing four vertices from the polygon such that the diagonals drawn between two pairs of these vertices intersect inside the polygon.
Calculate the number of ways to choose such sets of four vertices from the total n vertices.
Deduce the number of intersection points each set of chosen four vertices contributes.
Aggregate the number of intersection points contributed by all possible sets of four vertices to find the total number of distinct intersection points inside the polygon.

Determine the conditions for two diagonals to intersect each other inside the polygon.
Calculate how many pairs of diagonals can potentially intersect inside the polygon.
Consider that each intersection point of diagonals corresponds to choosing a subset of four vertices from the polygon.
Calculate how many quadruples of vertices can be selected from the n vertices.
Verify that no three diagonals intersect at the same point, ensuring that each intersection is determined by exactly one pair of diagonals.
Combine the information from previous steps to derive a formula for the number of intersection points as an expression of n.
